title: Epic: Add nanobind + viser visualization infrastructure
description:
Add Python visualization capability so students can visualize poses, kinematics, state estimation, and planning results. Uses nanobind for C++ bindings and viser for web-based 3D visualization.

Components:
1. nanobind build setup (CMake integration)
2. Python bindings for week3 types (position_t, quaternion_t, transformation_t)
3. viser visualization helpers
4. Example scripts for visualizing transforms, trajectories, etc.

Benefits:
- Visual feedback helps understanding
- Works over SSH (web-based)
- Hierarchical scene graph matches robotics concepts

title: Create example visualization scripts
description:
Create example Python scripts showing how to visualize student work.

Examples:
1. visualize_transforms.py - Load and display transformation_t objects
2. visualize_fk.py - Interactive forward kinematics (sliders for joint angles)
3. visualize_path.py - Show BFS/Dijkstra/A* paths on a grid

Each example should:
- Be self-contained and runnable
- Include comments explaining the visualization
- Demonstrate viser features (gizmos, GUI controls, etc.)

Students can copy/modify these for their own visualizations.

title: Create viser visualization helpers
description:
Create Python helpers that bridge our C++ types to viser visualization.

Helpers:
- visualize_frame(server, tf: transformation_t) - show coordinate frame
- visualize_trajectory(server, poses: list[transformation_t]) - show path
- visualize_robot_arm(server, joint_angles, fk_func) - show kinematic chain
- visualize_particles(server, particles) - for particle filter later

Uses viser's scene graph for hierarchical transforms (matches robotics mental model).

Dependencies:
- viser (pip install viser)
- numpy for array conversions

title: Create Python bindings for week3 geometric types
description:
Bind week3 types (position_t, quaternion_t, transformation_t) to Python using nanobind.

Bindings needed:
- meter_t, radian_t, degree_t (strong types)
- position_t with x(), y(), z() accessors
- quaternion_t with from_euler(), conjugate(), multiplication
- transformation_t with position(), rotation(), multiplication
- Free functions: distance(), near()

Should feel Pythonic:
- Support __repr__ for nice printing
- Support arithmetic operators
- Consider numpy interop for arrays
